params.text:
• Opening and Closing (Formal/Informal)
  • Saying Why you are Writing
  • Making Polite Requests and Saying Thank You

Professional Writing

Use Basic Email
Expressions

Language in Action
Professional Writing: Introduction

Welcome to this module on professional email writing!

Today, we have 3 topics

1. Greet colleagues

  2. Explain why you're writing

  3. Make polite requests or express thanks in your emails
Opening and Closing (Formal/Informal): Key Points

Emails use greetings and closings to show respect.
Greetings and closings can be formal or informal.
Formal Greetings:

Use formal greetings for someone new, someone outside your company, or someone in a higher position than you. Here are some common examples:

  • Dear Mr./Ms. Last Name: This is the most formal option. Use it when you don't know the person's preferred name.
  • Dear [Full Name]: This is a more formal way to greet someone you know by name.

Example: Dear Ms. Smith, (Formal email to a new client)
Informal Greetings:
Formal Closings:
Informal Closings:

Use informal greetings for someone you know within your company, such as a teammate. Here are some options:

  • Hi [First Name]: This is a friendly and informal way to greet a colleague.
  • Hello Everyone: This can be used when sending an email to a small group of colleagues you know well.

Example: Hi Sarah, (Informal email to a colleague)

Closings can also be formal or informal.
Here are some options to use at the end of your email:

  • Sincerely: This is a very formal closing.
  • Best regards: This is a formal closing for business situations.

Use informal closings only with colleagues you know in your company.
Here are a couple of options:

  • Thanks! This is a short and friendly way to close an email.
  • Best, This is another informal closing option.

params.scoreExplanation: Correct answers give +1 point. Incorrect answers give -1 point. The lowest possible score is 0.

params.text: Dear Mr. Johnson,
Hi Frank,
Hello,
Sincerely,
Best Regards,
Thanks,
Best,

params.text: Opening and Closing: Exercise
Which of these phrases can we use for opening and email, and which for closing?
Saying Why you’re Writing: Flashcards

dialogs.text: I am writing to inform you about...
dialogs.answer: Use this to tell someone something new or important.

dialogs.text: I am contacting you to ask about...
dialogs.answer: Use this to ask a question politely.
Use this to remind someone about something you previously discussed.
Use this to make a polite request.

dialogs.text: I am getting in touch to confirm...
dialogs.answer: Use this to check details or arrangements with someone.

params.textField:
I am writing to *inform* you about the new company meeting schedule. 
I am contacting you to ask *about* the deadline for the sales report. 
I am following *up* on our conversation about the project. 
I am writing to *request* some additional information for the project. 
I am getting in *touch* to confirm the time of our meeting.

metadata.title: Saying Why you’re Writing - Drag the Words

params.taskDescription: Please read the following email and fill in the missing words:

params.textField:
*Hi* Sarah,
I am writing to *ask* about the time for our meeting tomorrow. I remember we talked about meeting to discuss the new project, but I can't remember the exact *time*.
*Could* you please let me know what time works best for you?
*Thanks*!
Best,

Question 3 of 4: Do you have the _____ for the project?

params.text: Missing Word Quiz
Please answer the following questions to make useful sentences:
Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You're writing an email to someone you don't know well. How should you greet them?
Question 2 of 6: You need to know the deadline for a report. Which sentence best introduces your email's purpose?
answers:
I want to know about the deadline for the sales report. 

Thank you for your help!

See you tomorrow!

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: You missed a meeting and want the notes. How can you politely ask for them in your email?
answers:
Can you send me the meeting notes?

Send me the meeting notes.

I need the meeting notes.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: Your colleague helped you with a task. How can you thank them in your email?
Question 5 of 6: You want to know if your colleague has a few minutes to chat about a project. Which question is the most polite way to ask?
answers:
Can we chat about the project sometime?

Do you have time to talk? 

Let's talk about the project!

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: You received a helpful email from a teammate. How can you respond briefly to show your appreciation?
